name: 1 Anderson Road
description: 1 Anderson Road includes two apartments (one 5-person unit and one 6-person unit) for upper-class student housing. Both units are laid out in a duplex-like style with large living rooms and kitchens on the first floor and second-floor bedrooms accessible via private stairways. Both apartments are considered to be co-educational.

name: 100 College Hill Road
description: 100 College Hill Road is a duplex used by Hamilton for temporary housing. The first floor apartment has two doubles and a single, while the second floor includes two doubles and two singles. Each apartment is equipped with cable, high-speed Internet, a living room, a large kitchen and is substance free. These apartments can be coed or single sex, but the total building occupancy cannot exceed 60 percent of either gender.

name: 4002 Campus Road
description: 4002 Campus Road is a duplex that has six singles, three on each side. Each apartment has a living room and a large kitchen. One of the 4002 Campus Road apartments can either be female-only and the other male-only or both must be co-ed. Rooms in 4002 Campus Road are offered to sophomore, junior and senior students.

name: Afro-Latin Cultural Center
description: Founded in 1969, the Afro-Latin Cultural Center provides a place of solidarity for Black and Latino/a students and is the home to faculty in the Africana Studies Department. Open to the entire community, the center sponsors discussions, lectures, art shows and similar educational, cultural and social events.

name: Alexander Hamilton Statue
description: The statue of Alexander Hamilton commemorates the College's namesake and one of its first trustees. In 1793, the first secretary of the treasury and President George Washington supported missionary Samuel Kirkland's "plan of education," which began as the Hamilton-Oneida Academy and in 1812 became Hamilton College.

name: Alumni Gymnasium
description: The Alumni Gym contains a basketball court, weight room and locker rooms. It served as Hamilton's primary gymnasium until the Margaret Scott Bundy Field House was constructed in 1978.

name: Anderson-Connell Alumni Center (C&D)
description: Originally an inn called Lee's Tavern and the home of the Root family, the Alumni Center is one of the oldest buildings on College Hill. It is named in honor of Molly and Joseph F. Anderson, Class of 1944, and in memory of Clancy D. Connell, Class of 1912. It houses the offices of Communications and Development.

name: Azel Backus House
description: The only building still extant from the Hamilton-Oneida Academy, Backus House was constructed as a boardinghouse for the academy's students. In 1812 it became the home of Azel Backus, the first president of the College. Since 1958 the house has contained faculty and staff apartments and has served as a meeting place for various campus and alumni groups.

name: Babbitt Pavilion
description: The picnic pavilion is an outdoor social space located adjacent to Minor Field. It is used for picnics and other similar gatherings.

name: Babbitt Residence Hall
description: Babbitt is located on the south side of campus and provides housing for sophomores, juniors and seniors. Each suite includes a lounge area, a kitchen facility and a bathroom that is shared with another suite. In addition, Babbitt has a central lounge as well as several laundry facilities.

name: Beinecke Student Activities Village
description: The bright yellow clapboard buildings link the north and south sides of campus via Martin's Way, a red brick path named in honor of Hamilton's 16th president. Beinecke Village, constructed in 1993 and named for Walter Beinecke, Jr., former chairman of the Board of Trustees of Kirkland College and a life trustee of Hamilton, contains the Mail Center, Howard Diner and Fillius Events Barn, as well as lounges and a relaxing winter porch.

name: Benedict Hall
description: The gift of Henry Harper Benedict, Class of 1869 and one of the pioneers in the manufacturing and marketing of the typewriter, Benedict Hall, which was erected in 1897, houses classrooms and faculty offices for the Religious Studies Department.

name: Blood Fitness and Dance Center
description: When it opened in 2006, this state-of-the-art facility tripled the previous space for fitness activities on a campus where approximately 75 percent of students - and many members of the faculty and staff - work out regularly. Included in the building is a large, glass-enclosed aerobic/cardio training area that overlooks Steuben Field; two rooms for resistance and weight-training; a three-story, 39-foot climbing wall; a dance studio that can be transformed in 10 minutes from a working studio to performance space; and a multipurpose room. Spinning classes are held on bikes located on the second level cardio mezzanine overlooking the main aerobic/cardio area.

name: Bristol Swimming Pool
description: The award-winning Bristol Pool is an eight-lane "stretch" pool with a moveable bulkhead permitting separation into diving and swimming areas. It provides Hamilton with modern aquatic facilities that meet intercollegiate standards for competition and the needs of casual swimmers. The pool was the site of a successful world-record swim relay and has hosted several men's and women's New York State championships. It is named for the son of the Hamilton graduate who co-founded the Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.

name: Bronze Map
description: The bronze map provides a pictorial representation of Hamilton College in 1994. It was installed as part of the construction of Martin's Way, the major north-south pathway on campus.

name: Bundy Dining Hall
description: Bundy Dining Hall provides space for large social gatherings and special events. It no longer serves as a student dining facility, but is used by the College's food service provider for catering purposes.

name: Bundy East and West Residence Halls
description: The two buildings in the Bundy complex (Bundy East and Bundy West) are similar in structure and have singles and doubles. There are two apartments in each building for 4 people each, complete with kitchen, bathroom and common room.  Both buildings have lounges, a recreation area and laundry facilities. The rooms in these buildings are offered to sophomores, juniors and seniors and are coed by room.

name: Burke Library
description: Within the 80,000-square-foot library are the All-Night Reading Room, Information Commons, Multimedia Presentation Center, Rare Book Room, Special Collections and the College Archives. Including the holdings of the Music Library, Media Library and Fillius Jazz Archive, the library owns approximately 650,000 volumes. The Daniel Burke Library, completed in 1972, is named for a member of the Class of 1893 who was for many years chairman of the Board of Trustees.

name: Buttrick Hall
description: Originally built in 1812 as the student dining hall, Buttrick Hall is as old as the College itself. In 1834 it became the home of Horatio Buttrick, then superintendent of the Buildings and Grounds Department as well as registrar. Through Oren Root's marriage to a daughter of Horatio Buttrick, the building became the birthplace of Elihu Root, U.S. secretary of state and recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize. It has served as Hamilton's administrative headquarters since 1926.

name: Campus Road Athletic Fields
description: This facility provides a lighted artificial turf field used by varsity field hockey and lacrosse, and club and intramural athletic events. The lighted natural grass fields behind the turf surface are used primarily for varsity football practices.

name: Campus Safety Office
description: The Campus Safety Office provides services 24 hours a day by personnel who are an integral part of developing and maintaining a safe campus. The office is open from 7:30 a.m. - 11:30 p.m., seven days a week. From 11:30 p.m. - 7:30 a.m., a campus safety communication center is available on the first floor of the Bristol Center.

name: Carnegie Residence Hall
description: Carnegie is located in the main quad area on the north side of campus. Carnegie contains doubles and two-room quads. Each room opens into a large central study room with natural hardwood floors and wood paneling on the walls. Carnegie also contains a spacious lounge, study lounge, recreation room, laundry room and kitchen area.

name: Carriage House
description: The Carriage House serves as office space for the Administration and Finance department.

name: Cemetery
description: Many legendary Hamilton professors, presidents and other College dignitaries have found their final resting place on this two-acre plot. Among them are Samuel Kirkland, the College's founder; Oneida Indian Chief Skenandoa; and Nobel Peace Prize winner Elihu Root, Class of 1864.

name: Chapel
description: Designed by architect Philip Hooker and completed in 1827, the Chapel is thought to be the only remaining example of an early three-story church in America. Restored in 1949 as a World War II memorial, it is Hamilton's most notable landmark. The Chapel is frequently used for religious services, public lectures, concerts and assemblies. The third floor provides office and meeting space for the campus chaplaincy and the Community Outreach & Opportunity Project (COOP). The chapel space also contains a Muslim Prayer Room, a Meditation Room, and a library of books and videos from various religious and spiritual traditions.

name: Christian A. Johnson Hall
description: The former College library (1914-1972) was renovated and rededicated as Christian A. Johnson Hall in 1982. It houses the Quantitative & Symbolic Reasoning Center (QSR), Digital Humanities Initiative (DHi), Language Center, media library and classrooms and faculty offices for the Critical Languages and East Asian Languages programs and the departments of French, German and Russian Languages, Hispanic Studies and Mathematics.

name: Community Garden
description: The Community Garden and the 1812 Garden are located behind Woollcott House, and provide an area for the campus community to grow plants and vegetables.  Several classes make use of the garden space for research projects.

name: Couper Hall
description: Constructed in 1889 and rededicated in 1992 in memory of Edgar W. Couper, Class of 1920, Couper Hall originally served as the College YMCA building. It contains classrooms and offices for the Classics Department and Women's Studies Program.

name: Days-Massolo Center
description: The Days-Massolo Center promotes diversity awareness and fosters dialogue among the many cultures present on campus. The first floor includes a large gathering space, study space, a fully equipped kitchen and an office for the College's chief diversity officer. The Womyn's Center and two offices are located on the second floor. The building is named for trustees Drew S. Days III and Arthur J. Massolo.

name: Dunham Residence Hall
description: Dunham is the largest residence hall on campus with first year students occupying the basement, 1st and 2nd floors and sophomore, junior and senior students on the 3rd floor. Dunham has space for 252 students and consists of singles (3rd floor only), doubles and quads.  It is single-sex by wing, with the exception of the basement, which is co-ed by room.

name: Eells House
description: Eells House accommodates sophomores, juniors and seniors in single, double and triple rooms. The building features a large, wood-paneled living room, lounges and a laundry room.

name: Elihu Root House
description: Built in 1817 for Theodore Strong, Hamilton's first professor of mathematics, this structure has served as the home of College presidents and faculty members. The house was extensively remodeled after it was purchased by Elihu Root as a summer home in 1893, and was occupied after 1937 by his daughter, Edith Root Grant, and her husband, Ulysses S. Grant III, grandson of the president. A National Historic Landmark, it was acquired by the College in 1979. It currently houses offices for the dean of students, registrar and residential life.

name: Faculty Artist Studio
description: This bright, airy building serves as a painting studio and demonstration space for a professor in the Art Department.

name: Ferguson House
description: The rooms in Ferguson are offered to sophomores, juniors and seniors and include singles, doubles and a quad. The house is complete with a kitchen, dining room, lounge, study room, game room, laundry room and porch.

name: Ferguson Intramural Fields
description: The Hamilton softball diamond was created from the Ferguson Intramural Field in 1993 and renovated in 1998. It is home to the Continental softball team in the spring and sees intramural softball action in the fall.

name: Glen House (Outdoor Leadership Center)
description: Formerly a private residence, the Glen House was refurbished in 2006 and is home to the Outdoor Leadership Center. Hamilton offers numerous outdoor programs that take advantage of its close proximity to the Adirondack Park. In addition to the Outing Club and the Adirondack Adventure pre-orientation program, the building serves the Alpine Ski Team, Nordic Ski Club and Bike Co-op.

name: Gray Tennis Courts
description: The Gray Tennis Courts, located behind the Margaret Bundy Scott Field House, are home to the men's and women's varsity tennis teams. The nine all-weather courts are open for recreational use throughout the year.

name: Griffin Road Apartments
description: This townhouse apartment complex is located on Griffin Road across from the Tompkins Golf Course. The three buildings consist of 12 apartments with three or four students in each unit. These apartments contain a small kitchen, a patio, bedrooms and a large living area.

name: Keehn Residence Hall
description: Keehn is located in a cluster of residence halls near the Kirkland Glen on the south side of campus. The residence hall consists of only double rooms and is occupied by first year students. This residence hall has lounge areas on the second and third floors equipped with a kitchenette and some furniture. The main lounges on the first floor are larger and include television and furniture. In addition, laundry facilities and a full kitchen are located on the first floor.

name: Kevin and Karen Kennedy Center for Theatre and the Studio Arts
description: Opened in 2014, The Kevin and Karen Kennedy Center for Theatre and the Studio Arts is designed not only to develop the talents of students who major in and plan careers in these fields, but also to integrate creative work and performance fully into life and learning at Hamilton. Core areas in the building are the common spaces: large classrooms and an exhibition area where students display their work. Studios and workshops are designed for painting, printmaking, sculpture, woodworking, metals and ceramics, photography and other media, while the interdisciplinary digital arts suite provides space for video artists to collaborate with musicians, dancers, actors, poets, mathematicians, scientists and others. The fully equipped and flexible 175-seat Romano Theatre, with dressing rooms, a costume shop and support spaces, accommodates a range of productions, while the smaller Barrett Theatre is a laboratory space ideal for senior projects, class projects and guest artists. The center is named in honor of Kevin Kennedy '70, former chairman of the Board of Trustees, and his wife, Karen. Both are collectors of art and longtime supporters of the performing and visual arts at Hamilton.

name: Kirkland Cottage
description: The Kirkland Cottage is the oldest building on the Hamilton campus. Constructed in 1792 as the home of Samuel Kirkland, founder of the Hamilton-Oneida Academy, which later became Hamilton College, the building was moved from the foot of College Hill to its present site and later restored. The cottage is used by the senior honorary society, Pentagon, for its meetings, and for the matriculation of the first-year class.

name: Kirkland Gate
description: Created in 2002 by sculptor Jon von Bergen '63, along with assistance of Ava Bromberg '02, the Kirkland College Gate is adorned with leaves and the green apple symbol so closely associated with the women's college that operated on the Hill from 1968 until its merger with Hamilton a decade later.

name: Kirkland Glen (High and Low Ropes Courses)
description: Contained within the Kirkland Glen are the Class of '96 Ropes Course and the D'Agostino Forest. Several miles of nature trails are used throughout the year for walking, biking, running, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

name: Kirkland Residence Hall
description: Kirkland overlooks the main quad on the north side of campus. The fourth floor has four loft-style apartments with full kitchens, a living room and bathroom. The first three floors consist of singles and doubles.

name: Kirner-Johnson Building (KJ)
description: KJ, as it is often called, is home to the social science departments, including government, economics, history, sociology and anthropology. These connected buildings, which underwent extensive renovation and expansion in 2009, are home to the Arthur Levitt Public Affairs Center, the Nesbitt-Johnston Writing Center and the Oral Communications Center. Originally constructed in 1968 for Kirkland College, Kirner Building is named in honor of Juvanta H. and Walter R. Kirner, and the adjacent Johnson Building is named for Virgil E. Johnson. The facility features large, flexible classrooms and common areas, and the latest technology. The building earned gold certification from LEED, the nation's preeminent program for the design, construction and operation of high performance green buildings.

name: List Art Center
description: The Vera G. and Albert A. List Art Center houses practice rooms for music and faculty offices.

name: Little Pub
description: Located adjacent to Beinecke Student Activities Village, this restored horse stable and carriage barn contains a game room, bar, dance floor, fireplace room and other spaces for informal social gatherings.

name: Little Squash Center
description: Opened in 2006, the Little Squash Center is one of the finest facilities of its kind in the country. It features 10 regulation-size courts, including two with exhibition gallery seating.

name: Love Field-Pritchard Track
description: Love Field is a natural-grass facility that includes the eight-lane, all-weather Pritchard Track. The field is used for men's and women's varsity soccer events, including NCAA tournament games and the women's Liberty League championships. A new scoreboard was erected at the north end of the field in 2005.

name: Major Residence Hall
description: Major is located in a cluster of residence halls near the Kirkland Glen on the south side of campus. The residence hall consists of only double rooms and is occupied by first year students. This residence hall has lounge areas on the second and third floors equipped with a kitchenette and some furniture. The main lounges on the first floor are larger and include television and furniture. In addition, laundry facilities and a full kitchen are located on the first floor.

name: Mason Field
description: Mason Field is an all-natural grass field located on the South Campus adjacent to the Kirkland Glen. The field is used as practice space for the women's soccer team and hosts a variety of intramural activities.

name: McEwen Hall
description: Named for Robert Ward McEwen, 14th president of Hamilton College, McEwen Hall houses dining facilities, the Café Opus coffeehouse, the Fillius Jazz Archive, a cinema lab, classrooms, music practice rooms and offices for faculty members.

name: McIntosh Residence Hall
description: McIntosh is located in a cluster of residence halls near the Kirkland Glen on the south side of campus. It includes single and double rooms, as well as a two-bedroom single-sex or coed apartment for four students. McIntosh has lounge areas on the second and third floors equipped with a kitchenette and furniture. The main lounge on the first floor is larger and includes cable TV and furniture. In addition, laundry facilities and a kitchenette are located on the first floor.

name: Milbank Residence Hall
description: Milbank is comprised of single and double suites. Each has a common area, a kitchen and a bathroom shared with another suite. The building features a two-bedroom apartment for four students on the first floor. In addition, Milbank has multiple rooms with laundry facilities and a central lounge.

name: Minor Residence Hall
description: Minor is located in a cluster of residence halls near the Kirkland Glen on the south side of campus. It includes single and double rooms, as well as a two-bedroom single-sex or coed apartment for four students. Minor has lounge areas on the second and third floors equipped with a kitchenette and furniture. The main lounge on the first floor is larger and includes cable TV and furniture. In addition, laundry facilities and a kitchenette are located on the first floor.

name: Minor Theater
description: Originally Hamilton's first library (1872-1914) and later the College infirmary, this building served as a theatre from 1962 until it closed in 2014. Renovations are currently under way to transform the building into a student residence hall scheduled to open in the fall of 2015.

name: Molly Root House
description: Designed in 1915, the former family home of Molly and Elihu Root III '36 became home to the Art History Department in 2006. The building features two first-floor classrooms, a seminar room, conference room, slide library student research areas and faculty offices.

name: North Residence Hall
description: North is located in the main quad on the north side of campus. It includes doubles and triples and is a residence hall for first year students. The first and third floors house male students, while the second and fourth floors are reserved for women. The basement includes a small lounge with couches, a TV, a kitchenette, laundry facilities and a main lounge with furniture.

name: Office of Admission and Financial Aid - Siuda House
description: Built in 1917 as home to the Sigma Phi fraternity, the building was remodeled and expanded in 2007 for the Office of Admission and Financial Aid. Special attention was paid to the many historic elements of the building, which are painstakingly preserved. Named in honor of Joy and Chet Siuda ’70, a College trustee, the building provides a gracious and elegant welcome to prospective students and their families.

name: Peters Observatory
description: Built in 1975 and named for Christian Henry Frederic Peters, who in came to Hamilton in 1858 as the first faculty member to hold a Ph.D., the observatory houses an 11 1/4" Maksutov telescope and several smaller telescopes. A building next to the observatory provides workspace for students enrolled in astronomy courses. This structure is heated by solar energy and designed to permit experiments in this field. The observatory is located one quarter-mile from the campus.

name: Philip Spencer House (Business Office/Human Resources)
description: Renovated in 2002, the former Chi Psi fraternity house was renamed in honor of the fraternity's founder. It now houses the Business and Human Resources offices.

name: Philosophy Department
description: This building provides offices and meeting spaces for the Philosophy Department.

name: Physical Plant
description: The Physical Plant Office, also known as Maintenance and Operations, is located on Miller Road, adjacent to campus. The Physical Plant staff is responsible for the physical upkeep of the College, including custodial services, repair work and grounds.

name: Quad
description: The College's main quadrangle is anchored by Burke Library to the north, the Chapel to the East, the Christian A. Johnson Building and Root Hall to the West and Benedict Hall to the south. In addition to several residence halls, Buttrick Hall and Commons Dining Hall are adjacent to the quad, which plays host to everything from informal games of Frisbee to outdoor class gatherings in the spring.

name: Rogers Estate
description: Students living in Rogers Estate have access to kitchen facilities and are on a special meal plan, taking all meals except lunch at the estate. The building includes singles, doubles, triples and quads complete with a library, living room, TV lounge and a laundry room. Rogers Estate is offered to sophomores, juniors and seniors and is substance-free.

name: Root Farmhouse
description: Root Farmhouse, located next to the Beinecke Student Activities Village along Martin's Way, provides a unique atmosphere for 20 students. The most centrally located residence hall, the farmhouse consists of three apartments that each include a bathroom, living room, kitchen, laundry facilities and a front porch. The apartments, which are available to sophomores, juniors and seniors, are comprised of singles and doubles.

name: Root Glen
description: The Root Glen is a seven and one-half acre wooded garden and ravine located on the southern side of Hamilton's campus. It is home to some 65 species of trees (including a 120-foot Norway Spruce designated the tallest in the U.S.), many kinds of shrubs and scores of varieties of flowers. The Hamilton campus features an arboretum where trees are grown for scientific and educational purposes, maintained, labeled, cataloged and mapped. Adjacent to the Root Glen is the Grant Garden, which contains a collection of world-class tree peonies, hybridized by A.P. Saunders, long-time Hamilton professor of chemistry.

name: Root Hall
description: Given in 1897 by American statesman Elihu Root, Class of 1864, in memory of his father, Oren "Cube" Root, professor of mathematics, the building originally served as the Hall of Science. It now houses classrooms and faculty offices for the departments of Comparative Literature, English and Communication.

name: Root Residence Hall
description: Root is Substance Free and includes single and double rooms, which are offered to sophomore, junior and senior students. There are lounges furnished with couches, tables and kitchenettes located on the third and fourth floors as well as, laundry facilities and a kitchenette on the first floor.

name: Royce Baseball Field
description: Home to the Continentals baseball team, the Royce Baseball Field is located adjacent to the Athletic Center. Its infield was recently upgraded with new turf.

name: Rudd Health Center
description: Named for the College's 13th president, this building houses Student Health Services, including fully equipped examination and treatment rooms, and Counseling and Psychological Services.

name: Sadove Student Center at Emerson Hall
description: Built in 1928 as home to the Emerson Literary Society, the Sadove Student Center offers gathering places and meeting rooms, a photographic darkroom, a kitchenette, work areas and storage space. The building houses the College Bookstore and radio station (WHCL), as well as the student newspaper (The Spectator), student organization spaces, club offices and the Student Activities Office. Renovated and expanded in 2010, it is named for Steve Sadove '73, P'07'10, '13, chairman of the Board of Trustees and former CEO of Saks, Inc.

name: Sage Rink
description: The Sage Rink received new lighting, ice-making equipment and general structural enhancements when it was renovated, yet architects preserved the building's unique character as the nation's oldest indoor college hockey rink. In addition to the men's and women's varsity ice hockey teams and numerous intramural squads, recreational skaters and physical education classes utilize the facility.

name: Saunders House
description: Saunders House is located on the northwest corner of campus. This historic house provides students with a unique atmosphere and includes single and double rooms complete with a full-service kitchen, dining room, living room, laundry facilities and an outdoor deck.

name: Schambach Center (Wellin Hall)
description: Located between McEwen Hall and the List Art Center, the Schambach Center houses 17 teaching studios and practice rooms, a fully equipped electronic music and recording studio, a music library, faculty offices and two rehearsal halls. The Carol Woodhouse Wellin Performance Hall, a 700-seat auditorium with acoustics to rival any concert hall of its size, is the center's showpiece. Completed in 1988, the building is named for Hans H. Schambach '43, a longtime College trustee.

name: Scott Field House
description: The Field House, a 55,000-square-foot multipurpose structure, contains three regulation-size basketball/volleyball courts and seats 2,000 spectators. It also houses a six-lane, 200-meter running track and indoor courts for tennis, handball and racquetball. The playing surface can accommodate practice for outdoor varsity sports during inclement weather, and nets drop down for golf and batting practice.

name: Skenandoa House
description: Skenandoa features air-conditioned single and double rooms, each with their own bathroom, for sophomores, juniors and seniors. There is a two-person apartment located on the first floor with two singles, a bathroom, common room and full kitchen.  Lounges with furniture for studying and watching television are located throughout the building and there is a laundry room and full kitchen on the ground floor.  Skenandoa House is the oldest building in New York State to receive a Silver LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) certification by the U.S. Green Building Coalition.

name: Soper Hall of Commons
description: Commons is the larger of Hamilton's two dining halls. Bon Appetit, the College's food service provider, is an industry leader for preparing fresh foods using locally grown products. The Culinary Institute-trained chefs prepare a diverse menu of choices for students and employees, many of whom join students over lunch. Commons offers a full-service European deli-bar, meat and vegetarian entrees, an extensive salad bar, a pizza and pasta station, and even sushi. Fresh bread, vegetables and fruit, and desserts are among the regular offerings each day.

name: South Campus Intramural Field
description: Located adjacent to Mason Field, this field is home to Hamilton Rugby and is used for other intramural and recreational purposes.

name: South Residence Hall
description: This residence hall includes singles, quads, and two room six pulls. The rooms in South feature hardwood floors and are available to students in every class year with first year students who participate in the REAL program living on the 3rd and 4th floors and other class years living on the 1st and 2nd floors.  South houses 126 students and is wheelchair accessible.

name: Steuben Field
description: Steuben Field is home to the Hamilton football team. It is named in honor of Baron von Steuben, inspector general of the Continental Army and drillmaster of George Washington's troops during the War for Independence. On July 1, 1794, von Steuben laid the cornerstone of the Hamilton-Oneida Academy, which became Hamilton College.

name: Taylor Science Center
description: Renovated and expanded in 2005, the Taylor Science Center houses offices and laboratories for archaeology, biology, chemistry, geosciences, physics and psychology. The building was designed to encourage interdisciplinary work by creating collaborative opportunities among the faculty and students with teaching labs that foster hands-on research experiences. The complex contains a tri-climate greenhouse, auditorium, coffeehouse and more than 100 teaching and research laboratories. Students and professors are supported in their research by a 500 Mhz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer, scanning and transmission electron microscopes, and an X-ray diffractometer and fluorescence spectrometer. The chemistry supercomputer, biology laboratory for bioinformatics research, psychology statistics laboratory, general computing classroom and wireless computer connectivity provide state-of-the-art computing facilities. In 2011, the building was dedicated in honor of Edward '46 and Virginia Taylor, who established Hamilton's largest financial aid endowment and committed funds for faculty research in the sciences and arts facilities.

name: Tolles Pavilion
description: The Tolles Pavilion, located behind the Little Pub, was built in 2000 and is home to a broad range of activities from luncheons and workshops, to concerts and dances. The facility is equipped with dressing rooms as well as a data projector and 16-foot screen for movies and multimedia presentations.

name: Tompkins Golf Course
description: The Tompkins Golf Course is a nine-hole, 2,761-yard, par 35 course immediately adjacent to campus. There is no admission charged to students, who also use the course during the winter months for cross country skiing.

name: Wallace Johnson Residence Hall
description: The Wallace Johnson House ("Wally J") is a residence hall for first year students and includes double and triple rooms. The house has room for 20 students and has a large living room with cable TV, a small kitchen area and laundry facilities.

name: Wellin Museum of Art
description: Opened in 2012, the Ruth and Elmer Wellin Museum of Art joins traditional object-based learning with advances in interdisciplinary approaches. With its visible archive and open storage, the museum allows access to a collection of art and artifacts that span millennia and cultures. The building offers classroom space, a study center and a versatile exhibition space. By bringing the classroom into the museum, the Wellin functions as a "teaching laboratory," available to students and faculty alike. The museum also serves the broader community, encouraging observation, exploration and engagement through its presentation of exhibitions on the cutting edge of art, art scholarship and research in other disciplines. The museum is named in honor of the parents of trustee Keith Wellin '50, who, along with his wife Wendy, provided funds for the College's new arts facilities.

name: Wertimer House
description: Wertimer House is located near the Bristol Center, Skenandoa House and Wallace Johnson House. Wertimer has space for 42 incoming first years in 21 doubles. Since Wertimer houses only first years who are all coming to Hamilton together, the residents often form a close knit community. The first floor lounge is large with a pool table, flat screen TV and is usually buzzing with activity. Two upperclass Resident Advisors will also live in the building. Wertimer is wheelchair accessible.

name: Woollcott House
description: This house is located on Campus Road at the northeast corner of campus. It provides students with singles and doubles complete with a large kitchen, dining room, living room, laundry room and back porch. Students prepare and cook their own meals (except lunch) as part of a co-op.

name: ZipCars
description: Need to run an errand?  Want to get away for the weekend? Hamilton College students, faculty and staff have 24/7 access to two Zipcars parked on campus. Reserve your car online, let yourself in with your Zipcard and drive. The hourly and daily rates include gas, insurance and 180 free miles.
